lines: Set up your computer. (instructions)
Take some time to tell me about you. (link)
Bring your computer to class with you every day starting Wed.
Work for 30 minutes on LegoAd. (instructions linked below)
Be prepared to report one stuck point (solved or not) with your group.
Finish LegoAd. (see Definition of Done at the instructions linked below)
Work for 30 minutes on LegoAd. (instructions linked below)
Post one question or answer or tip about Lego on Piazza.
return signed research form (even if you are declining to participate)
do 'Loops' worksheet (printable)
do 'Math.random' worksheet (printable)
watch Shiffman's 8.1 "What is OOP" (link)
watch Shiffman's 8.2 "Defining a Class, Part 1" (link) and take notes in your notebook.
watch Shiffman's 8.3 "Defining a Class, Part 2" (link) and take notes in your notebook.
Finish Lightning. (instructions)
prepare for test Wednesday (review slides) (check homework solutions on Piazza)
do Practice with Classes sheet, then check solutions on Piazza
do 30 minutes on the Dice project (instructions linked below) -- use Piazza if needed!
return signed field trip form
do 'Practice with Nested Loops' (printable)
finish Dice (due 3:15pm on Thursday)

write a short sketch that creates one Bacteria object which moves in a random walk around the screen (you might find it helpful to reference the Chemotaxis slides #1-28, see link in Materials section of the class page)
optional challenge: write an additional class for an object that randomly jumps around the screen, and display it
do Part 2 and Part 3 of Chemotaxis
finish Chemotaxis.
read and do Java Arithmetic packet Part 1 (optional but recommended: also do Part 2)
read and do Compound Conditionals packet
finish Practice with Arrays of Objects, and check solutions (solutions linked here)
check solutions to Java Arithmetic Part 1 (solutions linked here)
check solutions to Compound Conditionals (solutions linked here)
if (you did the optional Java Arithmetic Part 2) {email me a screenshot of your code and output};
recreate one of these optical illusions in Processings
test corrections per instructions here
in your programmer's notebook, take notes on all the slides here
finish Starfield
read the 'array' slides linked below as Starfield follow-up slides
finish these codingbat problems (REMEMBER TO LOG IN) --> Warmup-2 > arrayCount9, arrayFront9 ... Array-2 > countEvens, bigDiff ... (optional extras = Array-2 > centeredAverage, lucky13, sum28)
read and take notes on the 'interface' slides linked below as Starfield follow-up slides
finish these codingbat problems (REMEMBER TO LOG IN) --> Warmup-1 > nearHundred, posNeg, or35, icyHot, in1020, makes10, intMax, close10, in3050 ... Array-1 > firstLast6, sameFirstLast, makePi
prepare for test Friday on arrays, objects, interfaces, and basic inheritance. use the 'Checkpoint 3' resources linked below
still feeling rusty on the last test? use the 'extra resources' linked under 'Checkpoint 2' below
do Practice FRQ: Sound trimSilenceFromBeginning
review for test (see materials under 'Checkpoint 3' below)
if needed: practice with our quizlet class. catch up! finish projects! study for retakes! hooray!
optional: watch this tutorial about making a photo mosaic with Obama-era White House social media photos and bring an interesting design to show us after Thanksgiving
finish these codingbat problems (REMEMBER TO LOG IN) --> Logic-1 > fizzString, fizzString2 and Array-1 > commonEnd, rotateLeft3
do the full assignment at ParticleSystem and be ready to share the result at the start of class on Friday

finish today's classwork (listed in the following bullet points) 'Today you'll learn why computers use binary and how to convert our 'normal' numbers into binary. This is a skill you will need for the AP exam.'
watch and answer the questions in these EdPuzzle videos (in this order): (1) (2) (3) (4)
find a volunteer amongst yourselves to print a copy of this practice sheet for everyone
do the practice sheet that your dear classmate printed for you (or if nobody printed it, do it on your own paper)
watch this video about arrays and complete the printable notes (linked in the video description, or pick up a paper copy from your folder in Mr. Smith's room)

read all the pages in the List and ArrayList section of the JavaReview website and solve all the embedded problems (except those on the 'More Practice' page). Be sure you at least *attempt* to solve all the problems. For each, use a pencil to sketch on paper how you solve the problem, then write your best guess answer, then check the website for the correct answer. If you get it wrong, read the explainations of the wrong and right answers.
watch this video about inheritance and complete the guided notes (distributed in class Wed or linked in the video description)
install Greenfoot at this link. heads-up: it's a large download so plan ahead if you're on a slow connection
do Greenfoot Tutorial 1 linked here and Tutorial 2 linked here
watch this video about state and complete the guided notes (distributed in class or linked in the video description)
watch this video about constructors and complete the guided notes (distributed in class or linked in the video description)
complete review packet (pick up a paper copy in the classroom)
be finished with Asteroids project packet #1 and packet #2 (nothing to turn in - just have it done on your computer)
use the materials listed under 'Checkpoint 4' below to study for test Monday on inheritance, state, and constructors. remember there are no retakes available for this test.
finish packet 3 of Asteroids (which we started in class Wed). the last part (adding two-player functionality) is optional.
(links for the following assignments are under Midterm Prep)
(paper copies of the guided notes are available in class)
watch the Paths video and complete the guided notes
watch the Boolean video and complete the guided notes
watch the Comparing video and complete the guided notes
there will be a short 'preparedness' quiz on these at the start of next class
finish Asteroids project (see link under Checkpoint 4)
(links for the following assignments are under Midterm Prep)
(paper copies of the guided notes are available in class)
watch the String video and complete the guided notes
watch the String Methods video and complete the guided note
there will be a short 'preparedness' quiz on these at the start of next class
(links for the following assignments are under Midterm Prep)
(paper copies of the guided notes are available in class)
watch the Numbers video and complete the guided notes
watch the Math video and complete the guided notes
there will be a short 'preparedness' quiz on these at the start of next class
review the topics you feel weakest on, and ask for help where you feel stuck
read the 'Reading: 2-D Arrays', and answer the questions at the end. PREPAREDNESS QUIZ NEXT CLASS.
do 2d Array worksheet #1
watch these two videos on EdPuzzle (total < 30 min): 7.1 and 7.2, and be ready for a short preparedness quiz
finish Background and Coding Phase 1 of MyFavoriteCellularAutomata
finish Phase 2 of MyFavoriteCellularAutomata
finish Phase 3 of MyFavoriteCellularAutomata
familiarize yourself with the rules of the game of Uno (by playing it with cards or online, or by watching youtube, or by reading Wikipedia)
write the callColor method (paper handed out in class and linked here)
follow steps 1 through 16.i of the set up your dev environment steps for Uno
OPTIONAL: try step 16.ii if you like, to watch one game be played
REMEMBER TO LOG IN TO CODINGBAT
then solve any two new problems from section Array-2
GOOD THING YOU REMEMBERED TO LOG IN TO CODINGBAT
then solve any two new problems from section Logic-2
I HOPE YOU REMEMBERED TO LOG IN TO CODINGBAT
Please take a few minutes to think about and fill out this WCS Product Pitch and Interest Form which is the first step in deciding what your final project will be

Use this answer sheet to do these 20 multiple choice problems from an AP Practice Exam. (You can skip #12, which we haven't studied yet.) Everything else you have at least some basic experience with. Do not spend more than 2 hours on it. Do not spend less than 30 minutes on it.
In the middle of your work time on those practice problems, take a break and listen to this 2-minute reading of Billy Collins' poem Thesaurus, which has nothing to do with Computer Science
finish what you started in class today: the first row of codingbat problems in the AP-1 section (scoresIncreasing, scores100, scoresClump)

implement all the code that we did in this video of our work in class, which is (1) updating the predicate at the beginning of the show function, (2) updating the for loop in the updateCellArray() function, and (3) complete the getNewCellState() method. You do NOT have to work on the getRulePatternAsArray() method which we were working on when the bell rang. If you want to use the same code I started with during class, there's a link to it in the video description.

we finished the live-coding of CA in class today, and you job is to implement what we did in your code. Here is the recording, in which we worked on (1) the getRulePatternAsString method, (2) the getRulePatternAsArray method, (3) finishing the updateCellArray() method, and (4) in the draw() function, uncommenting the call to the c.showLabel() method.
first register for Runestone here, entering WCS-CSA where it asks for Course Name
Runestone > Assignments > Exam Prep: Lists
Project Proposal due at the start of class. 1 per team
Practice: Lists (10 MC questions in Runestone)
More Practice: Lists (10 MC questions in Runestone)
Finish MyFavoriteCellularAutomata Phase 4

Take or optionally retake your Lists Test during the first 20 minutes of E block on Friday or Monday. important note: before you take the test you must earn 100% on the 'Practice: Lists' and 'More Practice: Lists' assignments in Runestone.
Reading: Advanced OOP Concepts
Practice MC: Advanced OOP Concepts
watch this video about the Mandelbrot Set by Mr. Brennan
go here to watch and annotate the video
study for 'Advanced OOP Concepts' test on Mon and/or Wed and/or Fri - you choose. the HW due Fri 3/23 must be done before you take the test.
an OPTIONAL Recursion reading is here

Complete the Recursion practice questions and then take the 'Recursion' test which will be offered during the first 20 minutes of class Mon 4/2, Wed 4/4, Fri 4/6. You choose which days you want to take the test. Best grade is recorded.

do problems #4, #4 (yes, there are two 'number four's), and #5 in the recursion practice packet. NOTE: THESE ARE CHALLENGING PROBLEMS. Do not aim for perfection! Try your best to apply the method we used in class to solve these. I'll ask the sub on Friday to collect your best shot.
OPTIONAL weekend homework: watch this 60-min summary of exam topics
write your own recursion problem with solution
(are you wondering what happened to those walkthrough videos I mentioned? they didn't happen. turns out it's harder to be a youtuber than I expected!)
be ready to give 'alpha presentation' for your WCS Product in class Friday (guideline here)

We will have your last series of Mon-Wed-Fri topic tests during the week of April 23-27. The topic will be a very practical computing problem for people who work with large amounts of data. It's called search and sort, or how to find what you're looking for in a large array.
You won't need to write code related to search and sort, but you will need to be able to read code and recognize what it's doing.

This is an interesting topic which is covered on the exam, but which we will not be going over in class. It's important that you give your full attention to this homework, and use your classmates, your teacher, and your internet to find answers to your questions.
search and sort homework part 1: watch this harvard lecture (starting at timestamp 18:50), which is a visual overview of the topic
search and sort homework part 2: do this runestone assignment which is a reading on the same topic, but it'll zero in on the parts that are important to know for the AP exam
search and sort homework part 3: do this runestone assignment which is a set of practice questions closely aligned with the AP exam
Finish 'FRQ Practice - Number Cube', distributed in class on Monday
Do these two CodingBat problems: AP-1 hasOne and AP-1 matchUp
[optional] do any two codingbat problems - upick
Do these two CodingBat problems: mergeTwo (with hint or walkthru) and commonTwo (with hint)

Actively read and *do* 'Cram Sheet' packet up through and including '4. Inherit the Wind'. Research anything confusing. Write notes and questions on the packet. Hand it in Friday at the start of class.
Actively read and *do* the rest of the 'Cram Sheet' packet. Research anything confusing. Write notes and questions on the packet. We'll discuss it in class on Monday.

u-pick--> make some time for dedicated exam prep and do one or more of the following: solve a practice FRQ, pick two codingbat problems from AP-1, study one topic you feel rusty on, ask a question about something you don't understand
